Research
text:
Methods & approaches

Bioinformatics 
Expertise in analyzing genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and epigenetics data. We leverage cutting-edge tools and algorithms to decode the intricate mechanisms of life.
Data Analysis and Statistics 
Proficient in designing and executing robust data analysis pipelines, ensuring accurate interpretation of complex datasets across various scientific disciplines.
Oxford Nanopore Sequencing Data 
Advanced skills in analyzing Oxford Nanopore sequencing data, from quality control to genome assembly and variant calling, providing comprehensive insights into genetic landscapes.
Bone Biomaterials 
Skilled in the synthesis and characterization of bone biomaterials, with a focus on their physicochemical properties and biological interactions to advance regenerative medicine.
Machine Learning 
Application of machine learning techniques to predict outcomes, classify datasets, and uncover patterns in biological and material science data, pushing the boundaries of innovation.

This broad expertise enables me to approach challenges comprehensively, leading to meaningful discoveries and innovative solutions.

SDG 3 ‚Äì Good Health and Well-Being
My research contributes to Sustainable Development Goal 3 by advancing data-driven approaches in health and biomedical sciences. Through the integration of bioinformatics, transcriptomics, epigenetics, and biomaterials research, my work supports the development and evaluation of regenerative strategies, particularly in bone tissue engineering. By focusing on in vitro models and predictive computational pipelines, I aim to improve the understanding of cell‚Äìmaterial interactions and to generate robust biomarkers that can ultimately support safer, more effective, and more sustainable healthcare solutions.


SDG 4 ‚Äì Quality Education
Aligned with Sustainable Development Goal 4, I am actively engaged in promoting quality education through scientific training, capacity building, and open educational resources. I develop and deliver workshops, short courses, and teaching materials focused on bioinformatics, data science, and reproducible research practices. By emphasizing computational literacy and critical data analysis, my work supports the formation of highly qualified students and researchers, contributing to inclusive and lifelong learning in science and technology.


SDG 9 ‚Äì Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure
My work directly supports Sustainable Development Goal 9 by contributing to scientific innovation and digital research infrastructure. I develop scalable computational workflows, machine learning‚Äìbased analytical strategies, and interoperable data resources that integrate physical, chemical, and biological datasets. These efforts strengthen research infrastructure and foster innovation at the interface of biology, materials science, and data science, enabling more efficient knowledge generation and supporting the translation of scientific advances into technological and industrial applications.

title: Projects
text:
Bone tissue provides mechanical support and protection, regenerating itself in minor injuries but requiring biomaterials in critical injuries. Osseointegration depends on the surface of these materials. This project proposes a machine learning pipeline that integrates physicochemical data from five biomaterials with transcriptomes from cells cultured on them, including cytotoxicity, proliferation, and cell adhesion, as well as public fracture data (single-cell RNAseq and spatial transcriptomics). The goal is to identify molecular bases of cell adhesion and develop predictive models to evaluate and optimize osseointegration in biomaterials.



Forensic genetics uses SNPs in genes such as OCA2 and HERC2 to predict characteristics such as skin, eye, and hair color. However, there are gaps in knowledge regarding complete haplotypes, linkage disequilibrium in different populations, and the role of epigenetic methylation in these traits. With Oxford Nanopore technology, it is possible to analyze long reads and DNA modifications, overcoming the limitations of traditional methods. This project aims to characterize the haplotype and epigenetic architecture of the OCA2-HERC2 region in samples from 1000 Genomes, integrating variants, haplotypes, LD, and methylation, generating a catalog with forensic and population applications.



DNA technologies have been used in forensics since the 1980s, with PCR-based STR genotyping as the standard. Oxford Nanopore has brought advances such as real-time and long-read sequencing. Phenotyping and forensic epigenetics are emerging as promising areas for predicting physical characteristics and obtaining additional clues. This study aims to implement whole genome sequencing with Nanopore and bioinformatic analyses to identify variants, haplotypes, ancestry, and phenotypic characteristics, following strict protocols for DNA collection, extraction, and analysis.
